reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThose with a voracious appetite for classic arcade games will eat this up, but others might find it a bit hard to swallow. If you're hungry for some old-school quarter-munching action, this game costs less than a bite to eat and is something you can sink your teeth into, so it'll give you something to chew on for a while.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was made by some degenerate furry, with their vore fetish at the forefront, and I thought I could just buy it, trash it in a review and move on, yet it's one of the best, most authentic arcade experiences I've ever had.

I mean look at this.[41.media.tumblr.com] What the heck am I supposed to say? I can't defend what this comic series is about. I don't know ♥♥♥♥ about it, but it kind of sickens me. However, if I astral project myself away from this and just think of the game as its own thing, well, I'll explain why I like it.

When I first started it, I was confused. First person perspective? Being able to move around? Why?"

Then it hit me when I was playing: The noise. The atmosphere.

The sound of the joystick
date: the click of the button. Playing with a 360 controller
recommended: I could swear I was playing with an arcade pad. There's no way you can replicate that in an emulated fashion unless you get yourself one
hoursPlayed: but even then. There's something about staring down into a simulated CRT monitor of an arcade machine that playing it as any other game wouldn't have given you. Arcade machines were something special - like a big bulky advertising box that wants to sell itself to you. (Or maybe a prostitute comparison is apt here?) Arcade machines were the kind of thing you dreamed of taking home with you
voteText: as opposed to some crappy home port no doubt Acclaim had something to do with.\n\n"Gon' E-Choo!" (I kinda don't like that name) is as it says on the tin: A 3 stage "platformer" where you collect letters (The paper kind. Although for awhile I thought they were white hats for some reason) while avoiding a gator and bees. Avoiding the gator is just plain fun
votesHelpful: where obfuscating simple AI patterns feels like you're tricking something - like showing a dog a mirror and it thinks its own reflection is another dog. There's not a whole lot to discuss here besides the sublime
commentsCount: does take its cues from Popeye - but you know what? I like Popeye
column16: but the game is different enough from it that it's not an outright clone. At worst
column17: I'd call it an extremely well done rom hack that adds new levels
column18: as opposed to how I think of it as an homage to a classic. (It even has similar Thru signs.)\n\nIn fact
column19: the game feels very much like a love letter to arcades. If you look around the room you're in
column20: you'll find fictional flyers and the guts/parts of an arcade machine you can examine. There's also a tape player you can blare over the music and sound of the game. (A nice touch is that you can turn off the arcade machines music and just leave the SFX on
column21: which is pretty awesome. Custom music tape mod when?)\n\nSo I've gushed about it. Any problems? Well... there is kind of one
column22: but it's not in the way you think. You see
column23: it's the controls. They're far too precise. With a keyboard
column24: the game works as you'd expect
column25: the problem is the Xbox 360 controller. It was never truly precise
column26: it's a good controller that fits a lot of games like a glove
column28: I got myself into a few too many pickles I knew I could have prevented if I was using something better. At the same time though
column29: I want to use a controller for this game
column30: cause it's the right kind of game for it.\n\nFor minor problems
column31: I guess the side panelling of the arcade machine could be more eye catching. I mean I could be wrong
column32: but how common are arcade machines with black and white comics on the sides of it? Maybe the power up could serve more of a purpose than letting you eat the gator? Maybe a mini game like a lot of later arcade games started adding? I don't know
column33: at this point I'm nitpicking.\n\nI know furries are a punchline
column34: but this more than anything proves to me that a person can have bad taste in fetishes
column35: but they can have supremely excellent taste in video game design. I think a lot of indie devs that think they're "totally like
column37:
man" could learn a lot from this title. I recommend it.

The Pro's:
+Feels absolutely authentic

+Throwback arcade design that's still fun today

+First person view adds a lot to the immersion

+The price is excellent
The Con's:
-Vore... furries... oh god

-360 controller is just too imprecise for such a precise game"
column41: 69 of 90 people (77%) found this review helpful 21 people found this review funny

reviewText:
The days of yesteryear are far gone, the arcades are nothing but a forgotten dream replaced with barcades and family fun centers, and a game like this (the game itself), would probably never be made for the mainstream.

Is Gon' E-Choo legit? Yes. It's the real deal. And for those who want a title that captures the magic, challenge, and replayability of a mid-80's arcade game, but something new. Here you go.

Feels like Popeye, vaguely reminds me of Mappy, and I would gladly let it eat my quarters any day if I were to see it in real life.

There's Easter Eggs, and everything involved with this title creates a lost world that time forgot, but never really existed.

The levels are fair enough to be playable, but still believably hard to be an 80's arcade title.

For the price, it's fair. On sale, it's a steal.

Give it a spin if you love old school hardcore. You wont be disappointed.

........I have a bad feeling I may get addicted soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very fun and quite difficult. The music and graphics are spot on for an 80's arcade game. I'm also really digging the overall look of the arcade cabinet.  Lots of nice little touches too, like the cabinet joystick moving along with the player's actions. I kinda geeked out when I saw scan lines on the game screen, simulating an old CRT monitor.

A treat for fans of arcade classics and totally worth the asking price.

10/10 will try to not get eaten again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty much like any other arcade game. As in, the mechanics are simple, you can get caught off-guard easily, there's a good bit of challenge as your pursuant gets faster and pauses for less time before grabbing for you, and if you know how the mechanics all work then you can try to pull off risky manuevers or just game the system and all that. Not to mention, besides the game, there's the whole arcade-cabinet-in-basement/garage environment where you're actually looking at the screen, hearing the music in that close environment through speakers, click of the joystick and buttons and all?

At any rate, for 2 bucks it's not bad. It's simple, the levels repeat (with growing difficulty), and the gameplay isn't hard to pick up, but grows challenging over time. I come back to it fairly often, mainly to give it another go and get farther, and also because I want to beat my friends' high scores because we're one-upping each other. So yeah, I think it's a fun little game.

By the way I should throw this disclaimer on here, I was the one who made the bleep bloop sounds and music, yeah. I didn't have anything to do with the gameplay or art or deciding mechanics or anything, though, I just supplied noises. I do legitimately think the game's decent, though, but yeah just putting that bit of transparency out there in case people think I'm reviewing my own product or something.

reviewText: Gon' E-Choo! replicates the feel" of a classic game better than any other modern retro game I've experienced. The others seem too focused on delivering the aesthetic (usually with too many colors) alongside gameplay that conforms to modern videogame expectations: there has to be an overarcing story
voteText: a difficulty curve that gently guides players to credits. Gon' E-Choo! doesn't do any of that. This game only sets out to deliver a new-one-of-those
helpfulPercent: and absolutely succeeds.\n\nWhile there's no explicit campaign
votesHelpful: the game does give you an overarcing goal: a notepad tells you the game can be broken to the point where someone can play it all day on a single quarter. But the only way to do this is the same way you'd exploit a classic arcade game: by learning the AI patterns to the point where nothing can surprise you. (There is a helpful cheat code
votesTotal: but even when it's used I can only make it to stage 57 or so.) I currently have a text file full of AI notes and stage strategies; it seems like I have it all worked out
votesFunny: I just need to get my reflexes to the point where I can do this in my sleep.\n\nThere is a motive for getting as far in as you can
commentsCount: from a this-is-merchandise-for-an-actual-brand standpoint: the webcomic has a cryptic side to it
column16: related to the gator's origin. The comic teases a letter that may hold some answers
column17: but it's only shown the first line so far. The whole thing appears to be in this game
column18: however; it's drip-fed line-by-line with every three stages you complete. But that's only a motivator if you're interested in the lore of a silly furry webcomic (which -- and I'm going to take a wild guess
column19: here -- I bet most people aren't). The game itself stands on its own.\n\nIf there's anything else in this game
column20: I'll update this review -- but for the amount of fun I've had with it so far
column21: I'd absolutely recommend it at $1.99. Get ate!~"

reviewText:
RECOMMENDED!

This is a fun and charming game that fans of old early-to-mid 1980s cabinet arcade games are definitely going to like. I don't remember playing a modern retro-style game that has transported me back to my quarter-crazy youth so enjoyably and thoroughly.

You play the role of a derby-wearing pink cat who is trying to collect letters in the form of paper airplanes that soar back an forth to the bottom of the screen. While running around collecting them, there is an alligator trying to eat the cat. Also, there is a power up that allows you to turn the tables and eat the alligator. This simple premise, like a good arcade game, is addictive.  A lot of quarters would have been pumped into this back in the day.

The sound is spot on for the chips that were used at that time and the music is a happy little jingle. The characters are unique yet familiar and could have had their own Saturday morning cartoon. The CRT screen emulation, animations, and graphics are straight out of a time-warp. For me, it really captures the atmosphere of playing an old cabinet game and it offers the fun of learning to master a new machine.

Some might not like the simplicity and repitition of a game with only three different screens (a treehouse in the woods, a backyard and a shopping mall) or appreciate the charm, but I think those people are going to be few and far between. And even at full price you can own it for less than 8 plays on a real quarter-operated game.

NOTE: The developer is very active in the forums and has already made some excellent updates since release.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGon' E-Choo is a mostly an arcade styled game with a little bit of first person movement. Apperantly this game is based off of a web comic series about a gator and a otter that's in the style of those old Pogo comics, I've read some of them and they are entertaining. The arcade gameplay plays just like the Popeye Arcade game, collecting trinkets to move to the next level, avoiding a big guy, etc. That's the main highlight of the game and it's good and challenging fun. Not sure what's the deal with the first person movement, aside from interacting with the arcade game, the only thing you can do is just look around and view parts and pieces to the arcade cabinet. But then again it's an early acess game so I can't be too critical, still feels like a finished game. And with its fun arcade throwback and cheep price, I say it's worth it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Man, I love this game! I remember playing Popeye on my friend's old Atari... Or maybe it was the Colecovision? Okay, I don't really remember the game all that well but I remember loving it.

What's not to love? You've got gators chasing you wanting to eat you, mysterious garage of wonders and old motherboards, and 50s style comics on a nearby table. It's a fun three-level game with an ever-increasing difficulty and an ending nobody has seen yet. That's right, you can be the first to see a kill-screen ending before EVERYONE ELSE. You'll get street cred. If you have to choose between 1 game featuring gators this year and you don't want to play Bayou Billy for the billionth time, get this game.

If this game has any problems is that the first level can be somewhat difficult for beginners. And I had a few other gripes, but with the game's newest patches a lot of the problems have been fixed. It's a game that's easy to pick up, difficult to master, and very fun and goofy.

Tl;dr version:

Gators. That is all. 19.45/10

This game is amazing outsider art and I can only hope it is the first entry in THE GON E CHOO THRILLOGY

you are trapped in a painstakingly detailed back room with no exit and there's a little muzak player and a locked refrigerator and a dead-eyed plush allygator and a kind of sort of eerie journal and you wonder if there's going to be some kind of metagame but there's no metagame, only GON' ECHOO

the last thing you will ever see or hear or feel, GON' ECHOO

beeping booping crawling scratching GON' ECHOO

quick collect all the little paper airplanes maybe that will somehow secure your freedom....?

but no

there is no escape from GON' ECHOO

bask in the unsettlingly smooth and detailed animation of the alligator eating the cat and then the cat turning into Giga Cat and eating the alligator

your last words come what might well be a lifetime later, a hushed death-rattle drowned out by the attract mode of the machine

gon'......e-choo""

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/wst1SYfSIEc

When locked into the back room of an run down arcade your only solace is playing a 1983 game known as 'Gon' E-Choo!'.  Exploring your cement cage will only result in locked doors and various promotional materials for 'Gon' E-Choo!'.  There might be a sub plot about child base diseases wiping out humanity.

The game you play in the game is a simplistic platformer where you collect paper airplanes while avoiding a crocodile trying to eat you.  However if you grab the power up on the stage you can turn the tables on old Croc and eat him instead.

Neither the game or the game in the game are interesting enough for more than a few minutes.

reviewText: I just got this in a bundle, gave it a go. I think it's a lot of fun, but that's because I'm an old-school arcade gamer. To me, the £1.59 price mentally comes up as 16 credits at 10p a go" and that doesn't seem like terrible value.\n\nIt's a lot like if you took a few early 1980s arcade games and mushed them together - it's mostly like Popeye - you collect falling floaty things before they get to the bottom of the screen while this big angry guy chases you
date: unless you get the power-up that moves about at the sides of the screen. The animations are very reminiscent of that original game
recommended: as well as the mechanics.\n\nThe animal theme and the inventiveness of the second level
hoursPlayed:
with the big tree and the way you can jump and springboard from one side of the level to the other remind me of Peter Pack Rat. It is a looooong time since anything made me think of Peter Pack Rat!

And "getting a power-up and eating the bad guy" makes me think of Pac Man. :)

The arcade game is
voteText: for some reason
helpfulPercent: in an arcade machine in a tiny dingy room containing spare arcade parts
votesTotal: and a tape deck with a piece of music that's like real people recorded the game's theme. I guess it's to add "atmosphere" to the experience
commentsCount: this just felt kind of lonely and claustrophobic. So I went into the options and made it display the game only.\n\nThe graphical style
column16: the font chosen for the text
column17: the music with its authentic sounding bloops and bleeps
column18: and gameplay are all the atmosphere I need. They are very faithful to arcade gaming of that era; I feel that a lot of love has gone into getting the small details right.\n\nThe one drawback is that the game has too few levels before it repeats. It's only got 3 levels. I mean
column20: Mr Do had 8 levels before it repeated
column21: and I think that's a fair number.\n\nSo - I would recommend this game
column22: but really only to people who already have fond memories of early 1980s arcade gaming. I don't know if it would hold the attention of anyone else."

reviewText:
i have been watching the development for Gon-E-Choo since i heard about it on steam greenlight and was happy when it was put on steam to buy, but is it worth the 2 bucks? (aka 8 games if you take into account of quarter by quarter play)

pros-

-the style of the game is very similar to nintendo's popeye, being you have to collect paper planes to advance to the next stage, use a power up to beat out the gator who is chasing you.etc

-the music is authentic to the arcade games it is trying to emulate, i could definitely put this in a arcade and it would fit right on in.

-the ammount of detail in the arcade parts and how the flyers make my arcade nerd squerm with enjoyment, a really REALLY nice touch to make the game feel more authentic.


cons

-no joystick support, yeah this has controller support but i planned to play this with a usb arcade joystick to get the full experience of playing a arcade machine, but noneless keyboard controls can do.

-(i know a lot of pepole are gonna attack me for this) the vore, now i dont mind vore one bit, im not into it but im surely im not sexually aroused by it. i see this game as a homage to its webcomic and the arcade games of yesteryear, not oh god furries and kinky crap ima buy this and downvote it" thats not the point i see here
date:
i see someone who made a game to make a tribute to arcade games and the source its referencing...and they did a damn good job at it.

do i recommend this game?

why yes i do
recommended: if you can accept that theres anthros and eating in it then go ahead
hoursPlayed: its worth the 2 bucks and if you get it as a gift
voteText: accept it..you might just like it.\n\n"
